contents.context:
U.S. stocks jumped on Monday on the hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine and the promise of more stimulus to revive an economy badly damaged by the pandemic.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged more than 911 points to close at just under 24,600.
The S&P 500 also jumped a little more than three percent, while the Nasdaq added around two-and-a-half percent.
The markets rallied on news that U.S. drugmaker Moderna reported positive early-stage results for a potential coronavirus vaccine.
Moderna saw its share price shoot up almost 20 percent.
Investors also have reacted to comments by Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell over the weekend, pledging more monetary stimulus if necessary.

"The Fed's interview on '60 Minutes' Sunday night indicating that they have not run out of ammunition and that they will do whatever it takes. That was then buttressed by the news, positive news of a virus vaccination."

South Korean stocks gained on Tuesday mostly because of the news about a possible vaccine.
The KOSPI gained two-and-a-quarter percent to close at around 19-80.
The KOSDAQ fell in the morning, but closed point-eight percent higher at around 696.
The Korean won fell around 7 won to close at a little over 12-25 against the greenback.
Yoon Jung-min, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Stocks rally on high hopes of possible COVID-19 vaccine
Updated: 2020-05-19 17:10:49 KST

contents.context:
First quarter profits at major firms in South Korea have taken a massive hit.
According to the Korea Exchange and the Korea Listed Companies Association, first quarter net profit for 592 companies listed on the country's benchmark KOSPI came to a total of about 9 billion U.S. dollars, down roughly 48 percent on-year.
Operating profit was also down by around 31 percent.
The damage was especially severe for companies in parts of the service sector that require face-to-face interaction.
Their net profit was down about 76 percent.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Q1 net profit for companies listed on KOSPI down 47.8% on-year: Korea Exchange
Updated: 2020-05-19 17:08:20 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's airlines plan to resume some of their suspended international routes next month.
Korean Air will start flying again to Washington D.C., and Seattle as well as to Vancouver and Toronto.
These routes were suspended around 50 days ago.
That means as of June, Korean Air will be operating 32 of its 110 international routes.
Asiana Airlines plans to resume 13 suspended routes next month, for a total of 27 to be in operation.
Korea's low-cost carriers have also started taking some international bookings.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean airlines to reopen int'l flights suspended due to COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-19 17:08:20 KST

contents.context:
From uploading job applications to getting that acceptance letter, the entire job hunting process in South Korea has gone virtual for the first time.
Instead of jobseekers going to booths at a convention center, they're going to an online platform set up by around 30 local SMEs.

"We provide all workers with educational expenses for their children every month as soon as their kids are born."

Jobseekers can freely ask their potential employers questions, and vice versa, from a convenient location of their choice.

"I think it's efficient, time-wise, for both companies and jobseekers in that we can skip unnecessary meetings. But it's also limiting, and it's unfortunate that I can't show them directly my qualities as a person."

Though talking through a screen could have drawbacks, some feel they can communicate just as effectively as if they were meeting face to face.

"These casual, online interactions enabled job seekers to ask questions freely and we were able to give honest answers which is more meaningful and realistic."

After uploading their resumes and self-introduction clips, job hunters will get a one-on-one final interview, virtually.

"We've decided to host the fair online this year because hiring and job hunting must go on, despite this COVID-19 crisis. No-contact hiring is very much needed, just like how the pandemic has changed work cultures."

"Over the next three weeks, around 300 people will be newly employed. This virtual hiring process could be a fresh, approachable opportunity, especially for young jobseekers who are used to mobile technology and to filming themselves.
Kim Dami, Arirang News."
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Entire job hunting process in S. Korea goes online due to COVID-19 concerns
Updated: 2020-05-19 17:08:20 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's two biggest tech giants Samsung Electronics and LG Electronics have seen an increase in their TV sales despite the shrinking global TV market.
According to market tracker Omdia, overall shipments of TVs worldwide shrank in the first quarter by 16.4 percent on year to some 43 million units.
But combined TV shipments by Samsung and LG were up 2.6 percent to more than 16 million units.
Their combined market share rose by more than 7 percent to almost 39 percent.
Samsung alone rose to around 24 percent, and LG to more than 14 percent.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Samsung, LG see TV sales rise in Q1 despite global market shrinking 16.4% y/y
Updated: 2020-05-19 13:29:26 KST

contents.context:
The South Korean private sector and government have announced a set of strategies to promote the country's bio industry in the post COVID-19 era.
The Minister of Trade, Industry and Energy met today with industry leaders, including the CEOs of Samsung Biologics and Celltrion, which makes biosimilar medicines.
The head of the Free Economic Zone in Incheon also took part.
He said that by 2030, the Incheon zone will seek to increase the number of bio firms there from 60 to 700.
It'll also grow the bio-related workforce from 5-thousand to 20-thousand, and boost investment from 7 trillion won to 15 trillion won, or about 12 billion dollars.
Also, the Free Economic Zone in Chungcheongbuk-do Province said it plans to attract more startups and train more biotech workers.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean bio industry presents post-corona strategies
Updated: 2020-05-19 13:29:22 KST

contents.context:
Time now for an in-depth look at the market news this afternoon.
And for that, I'm joined on the line by Mr. Daniel Yoo, global strategist at Yuanta Securities.
Mr. Yoo, thank you as always for making time.

Thank you.

Anticipation for a coronavirus vaccine helped send Wall Street surging overnight. The Nasdaq by about 2-and-a-half percent, the S&P by more than 3 percent. What's the story in the global markets today?





Korean stocks also higher today on those Wall Street gains. More than 2 percent on the KOSPI. Tell us a bit more about the details there.





Oil prices have recovered to around 30 dollars a barrel. Of course, that's far from the 50 or 60 dollars we saw at the start of the year. What's driving prices higher, and what's your outlook?





Alright, Mr. Yoo.
We'll have to leave it there for now.
Thanks so much for coming on today.
We appreciate it.
Reporter : devin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
In-depth: Global market wrap-up
Updated: 2020-05-19 13:26:51 KST

contents.context:
Samsung Electronics Vice Chairman Lee Jae-yong was in China Monday to visit one of Samsung's overseas semiconductor plants.
Speaking to workers in Xian, Lee said Samsung should not be held back by the past, adding it has no time but to move forward.
The plant has remained open throughout the COVID-19 pandemic.
This was Lee's first overseas business trip in four months.
He's also the first non-Chinese business mogul to visit China since the virus broke out in Wuhan late last year.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Samsung Electronics' Lee Jae-yong pledges to keep firm on upswing
Updated: 2020-05-19 10:04:44 KST

contents.context:
And now for your market close at the start of the week,
Optimism about states across the U.S. reopening their economies and signs of progress towards a COVID-19 vaccine perked up the market on Monday.
The Dow Jones ended around 900-points higher, or up nearly 4 percent.
The S&P 500 closed 3-percent higher to finish near 29-54 and the NASDAQ added around 2-and-a-half percent.
Oil prices surged above 30 dollars for the first time in more than a month on the back of production cuts by the world's largest producers.
Brent Crude was up over 9-percent at 35-47, while WTI jumped 11-percent to close the day at 32-dollars 72-cents per barrel.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Market wrap-up
Updated: 2020-05-19 05:59:42 KST

contents.context:
The Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry is set to become the first business group to receive the Van Fleet Award for promoting ties between South Korea and the U.S.
The chamber said Monday that it's being awarded this year's prize for its efforts to boost ties between business circles in the two countries.
The Korea Society has been giving out the award, named after Korean War General James A. Van Fleet, for over two decades, to honor Koreans or Americans who have promoted bilateral ties.
Previous awardees include U.S. Presidents Jimmy Carter and George W. Bush, late South Korean President Kim Dae-jung and Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-hee.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
KCCI awarded 2020 Van Fleet Award for promoting S. Korea-U.S. ties
Updated: 2020-05-18 17:06:01 KST

contents.context:
The South Korean government is moving to stabilize the price of fishery products during the off season by releasing supplies from its reserves.
The Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries says it will supply a total of around 6,70 tons of six products, including pollack, mackerel and squid, from today through June 10th.
Their prices will be 10 to 30 percent lower than usual.
They will first reach consumers through traditional markets, large-scale distributors and home shopping companies, and the remaining amount will be distributed through wholesale markets or the electornic bidding system.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea to release some 6,070 tons of fish reserves to stablize prices
Updated: 2020-05-18 13:29:54 KST

contents.context:
South Korea is holding a three-week virtual job fair starting today to connect jobseekers and employers in these difficult times.
Thirty-four small and medium sized enterprises are taking part, and are expecting to hire some 300 people.
The entire recruitment process, from applications to final interviews, is being done online, with no in-person contact.
It's being held by the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy together with Federation of Middle Market Enterprises of Korea and Industrial Bank of Korea.
More information can be found on the job fair's website.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean SMEs to hire around 300 employees in virtual job fair
Updated: 2020-05-18 13:28:50 KST
